did.abstract: The Elizabeth Heard Bell Papers include correspondence, diaries, subject files, clippings, and memorabilia. The subject files include material on many aspects of environmental activism, especially against nuclear energy.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Diaries closed for 20 years after donor's death, i.e., until Nov. 22, 2018.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Marcia Grimm in 1994 and 1999. The accessions not listed in this finding aid are 94S-26 and 94S-42.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Heard Bell (1908-1998) was born and raised in Summit, New Jersey. She lived in Paris for about 5 years in the 1920s, witnessing Lindbergh's landing in 1927. She married (?) Wadsworth, circa 1934, and had 3 children--Dewitt, Marcia, and Linda. They divorced and she married Stanley Bell and had a step-daughter, Ethel. Stanley Bell died in 1984. Both Elizabeth and Stanley were environmentalists associated with Montague Farm, a commune founded in 1968. They knew many local activists and were themselves anti-nuclear activists. She testified for Sam Lovejoy in the 1970s at his trial for destroying a nuclear power tower. In 1982 she published"Bittersweet: Poems&Prose."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
